<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/61  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 325, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 536, 90]]<|/det|>
The student measures the mass \(m_{\mathrm{D}}\) of a dish.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 100, 905, 120]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathsf{D}} = \frac{102.5}{9}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 910, 152]]<|/det|>
He places the ball in the dish and measures the combined mass \(m_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the dish and the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 565, 183]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 shows the dish and the ball on a balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 507, 214]]<|/det|>
Record the reading shown on the balance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 224, 635, 339]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.2</center>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 390, 917, 407]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{C}} = \text{......} \quad \text{g}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 603, 437]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the ball. Show your working.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[537, 484, 917, 501]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathsf{B}} = \text{......} \quad \text{g}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 501, 918, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 146, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 533, 593, 550]]<|/det|>
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the ball using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 562, 532, 593]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{m_{\mathrm{B}}}{V}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 917, 638]]<|/det|>
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 737, 917, 755]]<|/det|>
<form>\[\rho = \text{......} \quad \text{[3]}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 599, 88]]<|/det|> A student investigates the cooling of hot water in a beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 101, 410, 117]]<|/det|> The apparatus is shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[264, 128, 728, 267]]<|/det|>
Fig. 2.1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 313, 146, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 313, 918, 345]]<|/det|> The student uses a thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). Room temperature is \(22^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 357, 492, 374]]<|/det|> On Fig. 2.2, show clearly the reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 390, 846, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 460, 470, 479]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 483, 920, 501]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 511, 148, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 511, 920, 543]]<|/det|> The student pours \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into an empty beaker. She records the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water in the \(V = 100 \text{cm}^3\) row of Table 2.1, as shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 555, 918, 603]]<|/det|> Without delay, she pours \(20 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker. She stirs the water and measures the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water. She repeats the procedure until she has added a total of \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 616, 840, 632]]<|/det|> All the readings are shown in Table 2.1. \(V\) is the total volume of water in the beaker. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 644, 520, 660]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 644, 920, 661]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 705, 645, 939]]<|/det|>
\(V/\)\(\theta/\)
10087
12073
14065
16059
18054
20049
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 949, 546, 959]]<|/det|> 0625/61/M/J/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of temperature \(\theta\) (y-axis) against total volume of water \(V\) (x-axis). You do not need to start the axes at the origin (0, 0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 350, 135]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit curve.

<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 621, 149, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
In the experiment, the student aims to investigate the effect on the temperature of the hot water as cold water is added.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 668, 181, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 668, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
Complete the sentence to explain why it is important to add the cold water without delay at each stage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 714, 917, 730]]<|/det|>
The cold water is added without delay ....................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 777, 920, 795]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 806, 181, 825]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 806, 855, 823]]<|/det|>
Complete the sentence to explain the reason for stirring the water at each stage.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 836, 917, 853]]<|/det|>
The student stirs the water before recording the temperature ............................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 899, 920, 917]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 535, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates reflections in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 102, 432, 119]]<|/det|>
A ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 128, 850, 780]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[808, 783, 855, 820]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 783, 999, 820]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 844, 532, 860]]<|/det|>
# Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 870, 148, 889]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 870, 918, 935]]<|/det|>
• Draw a normal to the line MR that passes through the centre of MR. Label the normal NL. • Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B. • Draw a line 10.0 cm long from B at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^{\circ}\) to the normal below MR and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 932, 922, 950]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 777, 90]]<|/det|>
The student places the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 512, 120]]<|/det|>
He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , on line AB.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 133, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
Mark the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) with crosses (X) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 180, 918, 227]]<|/det|>
The student views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) , so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are shown on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 240, 181, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 240, 918, 257]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Continue the line until it meets MR. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 271, 183, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 271, 918, 301]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the horizontal line MR. An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 316, 918, 332]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) ............................................................ ° [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 148, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 345, 918, 376]]<|/det|>
The student turns the mirror through \(180^{\circ}\) . He draws a new incident ray at an angle of incidence \(i = 50^{\circ}\) to the normal above MR and to the left of the normal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 390, 918, 420]]<|/det|>
He labels the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\) . This line is **not** shown on Fig. 3.1. You may draw the line on Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 434, 918, 464]]<|/det|>
He places two pins on the line \(\mathbf{CB}\) and views the images of the two pins from near the top right-hand corner of the ray-trace sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 479, 918, 508]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, draw a reflected ray \(10.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) with an angle of reflection \(\beta\) equal to the angle of incidence. Label the end of the line \(\mathbf{D}\).

State **two** techniques that you use in this type of experiment to obtain an accurate ray trace.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 845, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 420, 120]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 400, 149]]<|/det|>
· wires with different diameters

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 151, 547, 165]]<|/det|>
· instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 168, 245, 180]]<|/det|>
· metre ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 184, 235, 195]]<|/det|>
· ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 199, 237, 210]]<|/det|>
· voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 215, 272, 227]]<|/det|>
· power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 243, 702, 258]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 273, 794, 288]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 295, 915, 336]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) , where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 535, 366]]<|/det|>
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 382, 224, 396]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 412, 562, 426]]<|/det|>
· draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 429, 494, 443]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 445, 484, 458]]<|/det|>
· state **one** key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 460, 915, 490]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 491, 598, 505]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.
